biblScope.title: Tarltons Ie∫ts.
Drawne into three parts
1 His Court-wittie Ie∫ts
2 His ∫ound Cittie Ie∫ts.
3 His Country prettie Ie∫ts.
Full of Delight, Wit, and hone∫t Myrth.

imprint.distributor: Printed for Iohn Budge, and are to be ∫old at his shop, at the great South doore at Paules. 1613.

div.ab: Upon a time, Tarlton was wrongfully accused for getting of a gentleman's maid with child, and for the same brought before a justice in Kent, which justice said as followeth : It is a mervaile, M. Tarlton, that you, being a gentleman of good qualitie, and one of her majesties servants, would venture thus to get maides with childe. Nay, rather, quoth Tarlton, were it marvell, if a maid had gotten me with child.

head.title: Tarlton deceived by a country wench.

div.ab: Tarlton travelling to play abroad, was in a towne where, in the inne, was a pretty maid, whose favour was placed in a corner of Tsrlton's affection: and talking with her, shee appoynted to meet him at the bottom of a paire of staires. Night and the houre came, and the maid subtily sent downe her mistresse ; whome Tarlton catching in his armes, Art come, wench ? saies hee. Out, alas, sayes the mietres, not knowing who it was. Tarlton, hearing it was the mistris, start aside, and the maid came downe with a candle, and she espyed a glimpse of Tarlton in the darke, who stept into another roome. How now, mistres ? said the maid. Something, said shee, affrighted me ; some man, sure, for I heard him speake. No, no, mistresse, said the maid ; it is no man ; it was a bull calf that I shut into a roome till J oho, our pounder, came to have pounded him for a stray. Had I thought that, saith she, I would have hit him such a knocke on his forehead that his home should never have grac'd his coxcombe ; and so she departs up againe, afraid. But how Tarlton tooke this jest, think you.

head.title: How Tarlton could not abide a cat, and deceived himselfe.

div.ab: In the country, Tarlton told his oastesse he was a conjuror. 0, sir, sayes she, I had pewter stolne off my shelfe the other day; help me to it, and I will forgive you all the pots of ale you owe mee, which is sixteene dozen. Sayes Tarlton, To morrow morning the divell shall helpe you to it, or I will trounce him. Morning came, and the oastesse and he met in a roome by themselves. Tarlton, to passe the time with exercise of his wit, with circles and tricks falls to conjure, having no more skill then a dogge. But see the jest, how contrarily it fell out : as he was calling out, mons, pons, simul, and sons, and such like, a cat, unexpected, leapt from the gutter window ; which sight so amazed Tarlton, that he skipt thence and threw his hostesse downe, so that he departed with his fellowes, and left her hip out of joynt,, being then in the surgeons hands, and not daring to tell how it came.

Once upon a time, Tarlton was wrongfully accused for impregnating a gentleman’s maid and was then brought before a justice in Kent. The justice said, “It is remarkable that you, M. Tarlton, being a gentleman of good quality, and one of her majesty's servants, would commit to such act.” Tarlton responded, “No, it would be more remarkable if a maid had gotten me with child.”
While Tarlton was traveling to play abroad, he stayed in a town with an inn where there was a pretty maid. He placed this woman in a corner of his affection. Talking with her, they agreed to meet at the bottom of a pair of stairs. The time came, and the maid subtly sent down her mistress, whom Tarlton caught in his arms. He said “Is the wench coming?” The mistress replied “No.” because she did not know who he was. Tarlton heard it was the mistress, and stepped aside. The maid came down with a candle, catching a glimpse of Tarlton in the dark, who had just stepped down into another room. “What happened?” said the maid to the mistress. The mistress replied, “Something scared me. I’m certain I heard some man speak. No, no. It was no man. I am sure it was a bull caf that I shut into a room until the pounder comes to pound him as a stray. If I had thought he was a man, I would have hit him with such a knock on his forehead he would never be able to reach his home.” And so, the mistress departed up once again, afraid. How Tarlton took this jest, one can only imagine.
In the country, Tarlton told his hostess he was a conjuror. She said, “Oh sir, I had powder stolen off my shelf the other day. Help me to it, and I will forgive you of all the sixteen pots of ale you owe me.” Tarlton says, “Tomorrow morning the devil shall help you to it, or I will trounce him.” The morning came, and he met the hostess in a room alone. Tarlton passed time with the exercise of his wit, with circles and tricks, having no more skill than a dog. Contrary to expectation, it fell out as he was calling out. And thus, like a cat, it unexpectedly leapt from the gutter window. This sight amazed Tarlton so much that he skipped ahead and threw his hostess down, departing with his friends and leaving her hip disjointed. He regarded her in the hands of the surgeon, and did not dare to tell how it happened.
